text: and we currently don't actually provision any infrastructure for each app created -- it's all multitenant shared infrastructure right now which is either insane or brilliant, we aren't sure yet. i like the idea of the multitenancy because it lets you super elastically burst and really take advantage of the cloud-ness of a platform like us, you don't have to write any autoscaling code or bake any AMIs or docker containers, it's all done for you, *including* the database part. I used to work on Shopify's flash sale platform a bunch and I think it informed a lot of my thinking about all of this -- it's really cool for a platform to be able to offer individual tenants access to an unfairly large share of the platform's resources for the select few times they need them, and then not charge them for it all the time, it's something that only platforms can do

text:
<@U016LEA3J1H> Makes sense, thanks for the clarifications! Ameliorating costs across your user base is a good strategy - in fact, if you think about it, GCP/AWS are essentially doing the same thing. Even if you do try to maintain the illusion of "owning your architecture" by deploying CF or terraform yourself.

The main difference being trust - hosted backends run the risk of tying each tenant's success to Gadget's success without a good ejection strategy. Given the serverless nature of the project I don't imagine such an exit strategy would be too difficult to implement, but it's a concern people will have.

text: one thing that makes me feel a bit crazy is that the big clouds don't seem to be building very many multi tenant datastores. They're definitely doing compute and making the grain of elasticity ever lower, but for most of the stateful stuff you need to specify your resource demands up front and then changing those demands is generally pretty slow

text: Yeah, agreed. There's also the funny slightly-tinfoil hat explanation that much of it is potentially intentional, or more strictly speaking not a business priority. Good auto-scaling and the equivalent of computational insurance policies would just shave margins of what I suspect is a fat cash-cow from poorly setup auto-scaling groups or lazy devs. It'd be really interesting to see how much of the gap between developer expectation of computational load and actual load translates into profit for cloud vendors.
